Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Defining a Disruptive Biorefinery Concept

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Mascal, Mark
Proposal Number: 1335646
Institution: University of California-Davis
Title: SusChEM: Defining a Disruptive Biorefinery Concept

This proposal describes the concept of a fully chemical-catalytic biorefinery, involving at no point either fermentative or thermal biomass processing methods. The outcome will be an exceptionally efficient, versatile system for converting biomass into renewable, drop-in automotive fuels, chemicals, and combustible solids for power generation.

The first part of the project examines operationally simple, irreversible C-C coupling reactions that lead to extended carbon backbones in sugars. The electrochemical coupling of biomass-derived pentoses and hexoses to give C10-12 glycitols is proposed; an industrially relevant reaction that uses the cheapest possible reagent-the electron. The PI will also investigate the anodic decarboxylation of the C6 acid gluconate, which can lead to a C10 macrosugar, as well as the products of the Kolbe electrolysis of corresponding diacid salt (glucarate). These molecules, when submitted to the hydrodeoxygenation protocol described below, will give linear C10+ hydrocarbons, which are the main constituents of diesel fuel and feedstocks for a plethora of petroleum-based chemicals. A head-start advantage here is that the target coupling products, both reductive and oxidative, have previously been observed as side products of other reactions.

The second part of the project catalytically reduces extended glycitols to linear alkanes under gentle conditions which do not lead to C-C bond cleavage. This becomes a possibility due to the powerful tendency of sugar alcohols to form cyclic ethers under acidic conditions, and the relative ease with which cyclic ethers can be reductively cleaved by hydrogenation in the presence of a strong acid.

The broader impacts in terms of research infrastructure and diversity lie in the program?s interdisciplinary nature, encompassing at various points organic electrochemistry, catalysis, biphasic reaction dynamics, and interactions with power systems engineers. The educational goals of the proposal are closely linked to the PI?s research as well as his interests in pedagogical innovations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We live in the midst of what can be called 'the petroleum economy,' where most of our energy, fuels, and synthetic materials are derived from fossil hydrocarbon resources. The antithesis of the petroleum economy is the sustainable chemistry movement, which is organized around three opposing arguments involving economic, political, and environmental matters. The economic debate is simply that the cost of importing petroleum is a burden to the US economy, and that sustainable chemistry (deriving fuels and materials from agricultural, forestry and municipal wastes) is ultimately going to prove more economical. Political motivations involve national energy independence in a time when much of the global petroleum supply is in the hands of unstable governments. The environmental argument centers on the proposition that the unabated use of current fossil fuel reserves will have serious, potentially irreversible consequences for the global climate.

This research projects seeks to convert refuse such as straw, sawdust, and green waste into biofuels and renewable materials using electricity. Since electricity can be generated from solar power, it is possible to make automotive fuels and durable goods (plastics, textiles, coatings, etc) without the direct involvement of any fossil fuel. This has the potential to be a "disruptive innovation" in the sustainable chemistry (or "biorefinery") movement, displacing a significant volume of petroleum from the economy. The concept is rendered graphically in Figure 1, and the lab-scale experimental setup is shown in Figure 2.

Referring to Figure 1, we subject simple, natural carbohydrate derivatives to an electric current, which serves to couple them together. This results in the generation of larger molecules, particularly in terms of the number of carbon atoms, which are more useful for industrial purposes. These coupled molecules have been used to make fuels you could actually put in your gas tank. We have also used them to produce some novel renewable plastics. We are currently testing this electrochemical coupling method on other natural molecules to broaden the market scope of the technology. We are also working on scaling up this inexpensive process to show that it can be practiced commercially.

The activities in this project have provided opportunities for research, teaching, and mentoring in STEM, and have variously involved the training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, providing them a strong foundation in the technologies necessary for continued work towards an energy-independent USA. The project has also involved international collaborations.

The products of this research, should the technology enter commercial practice, have the potential to impact economic and environmental conditions in the US by providing inexpensive alternatives to the use of petroleum.
